listitem.para: The time until the acquire kernel state times out.

On-demand connections (such as Opportunistic, auto=ondemand, or ipsec route) have an IPsec trap policy installed in the kernel. If an outgoing (or inbound) packet matches this policy, a state is created in the kernel and then the kernel sends an ACQUIRE message to the IKE daemon pluto. While this state is in place, no new acquires will come in for this connection. The default should be fine for most people. One use case of shortening these is if opportunistc encryption is used towards cloud instances that can quickly re-use IP addresses.
The default, on &Linux;, as determined by /proc/sys/net/core/xfrm_acq_expires, is 30 seconds (30s). On BSD, this option is ignored.
Prior to &Libreswan; version 5.3 this option was called xfrmlifetime.
